info.game_comments:
2005 College Championship quarterfinal game 1.
From the RBC Center in Raleigh, North Carolina.

(1, 1).clue: Kwame Nkrumah, later a pioneer of independence for this continent's colonies, went to Pennsylvania's Lincoln University

(3, 1).clue: This capital of Venezuela has a population of about 3 million

(4, 1).clue: Arranging a lovers' meeting in a crypt is a really bad idea--just look at Act V, Scene 3 of this play

(5, 1).clue: Sorry, this company doesn't Supersize its Fruit & Walnut or California Cobb salads

(6, 1).clue: In French, the name of this fancy dining room fixture means "something that holds candles"

(1, 2).clue: In 1993 Google co-founder Sergey Brin graduated from Maryland with honors in math & this field

(3, 2).clue: Calcutta was once the capital of India; this "New" city was made the capital in 1931

(4, 2).clue: Never promise anybody a pound of this; Antonio did, & Shylock tried to collect it (ouch!)

(5, 2).clue: If you need to drop a couple of hundred pounds, try this chain's 6" Turkey or Veggie Delite sandwiches

(6, 2).clue: The name of the U.S. state is partly from the French word for "green"

(1, 3).clue: Dwight Eisenhower lived in the same Kansas home from the age of 8 until he went off to this school at age 20

(3, 3).clue: It's the northernmost capital city in mainland North America

(4, 3).clue: Never trust a woman whose words are too flattering--like Goneril in this play

(5, 3).clue: Ring up a lower-fat meal by asking for a "Fresco Style" Chalupa or Gordita at this restaurant

(6, 3).clue: This synonym for bravery comes from the Old French for "heart"

(1, 4).clue: This 19th century "Children's Hour" poet attended Bowdoin College & returned to teach there

(3, 4).clue: One of the 2 national capital cities located on the island of Hispaniola

(4, 4).clue: Losing a hanky might lead to some deadly hanky-panky--I learned it from this play

(5, 4).clue: Try this franchise's Crispy Caesar Salad & a Lil' Bucket Strawberry Shortcake for dessert

(6, 4).clue: The name of this type of vehicle is a shortened version of the French for "walking hospital"

(1, 5).clue: In 1944 he entered Atlanta's Morehouse College as a 15-year-old struggling with religions doubts

(3, 5).clue: South Africa actually has 3 capitals: Bloemfontein, Cape Town & this one

(4, 5).clue: Heed this "Hamlet" character's advice that "the apparel oft proclaims the man"

(5, 5).clue: Have it your fat-conscious way with the Fire-grilled Shrimp Garden Salad or the Croissan'wich from here

(6, 5).clue: This word for an alpine cottage comes from the Swiss French for "shelter"

(1, 1).clue: She turned heads as a cheerleader at North Myrtle Beach High before turning letters on "Wheel of Fortune"

(2, 1).clue: (Hi, I'm Bill Rancic of The Apprentice.)  My boss Donald Trump has made this 2-word catchphrase his own; I just hope he never says it to me

(3, 1).clue: Of the U.S. coins currently being minted, it's the smallest in size

(4, 1).clue: Make a statement about the infantilization of consumers with a foof chair, which resembles this "bag" chair

(5, 1).clue: At the 2005 British Open, this "Golden Bear" played in what he said would be his final major golf tournament

(6, 1).clue: In legend, this pure knight found the Holy Grail

(1, 2).clue: In June 2005 more than 230,000 attended this 86-year-old North Carolinian's New York Crusade

(2, 2).clue: Celebrities who've appeared on this show, now on VH1, include Corey Feldman & Bronson Pinchot

(3, 2).clue: Before the euro, the peseta in this country equaled 100 centimos

(4, 2).clue: You can find a floral bedding ensemble from these "N Things", founded in 1975

(5, 2).clue: FDR gave his final one of these radio addresses June 12, 1944

(6, 2).clue: The 2 U.S. states that fit the category (sorry, Alabama has 4)

(1, 3).clue: Like his late dad, "The Intimidator", this NASCAR hotshot has also made a career on the fast track

(2, 3).clue: Evan Marriott, a construction worker, was the prize up for grabs on this series

(3, 3).clue: This national park noted for its geysers was placed on a commemorative U.S. silver dollar in 1999

(4, 3).clue: Evoke psychedelia with this type of poster whose fluorescent colors glow in the dark under UV radiation

(5, 3).clue: First performed in London in 1896, "The Grand Duke" was the final one of their Savoy operettas

(6, 3).clue: Sing out this 2-word musical term, from the Italian from "in the manner of a choir"

(1, 4).clue: This fiery civil rights leader seen here hails from Greenville, South Carolina

(2, 4).clue: On this show in 2003, Trista gave Ryan the final rose, he gave her a ring & they were later married on TV

(3, 4).clue: Of the 12 words that appear on every currently circulated U.S. quarter, this Latin word is the shortest

(4, 4).clue: Instead of a car or a girlfriend, consider a screensaver of the High Gothic cathedral in this Northwest French city

(5, 4).clue: In contrast to James Joyce, Joseph Heller titled his final novel "A Portrait of an Artist" as this

(6, 4).clue: Pertaining to farmers, it means rural or agricultural

(1, 5).clue: Internet users have South Carolina-born sci-fi author William Gibson to thank for this 10-letter term

(2, 5).clue: One "Survivor" locale was the Shaba Game Reserve in this country

(3, 5).clue: It's the "silly" nickname for Canada's one-dollar coin

(4, 5).clue: These storage blocks seen here lend an airy, geometric touch to a space

(5, 5).clue: In 1955 this admiral made his fifth & final expedition to Antarctica

(6, 5).clue: Any land of promise, it's the Biblical name of Palestine

(0, 0).clue: He declined the offer to lead a country & once said, "Politics is for the present... an equation is... for eternity"
